text: deep within the forests and lakes of
northern Minnesota is a place that
epitomizes the phrase company town this
is war road the home of Marvin windows
and doors change often times x is
difficult is very difficult I've been
through some very good times here in
some slower times in our industry this
is probably the slowest I've ever seen
it as far as the industry is concerned
and people here I think are just
incredibly grateful you know to to be
employed right now because you you know
if you watch enough television and read
enough newspapers you realize that's not
the case in all parts of the country the
recession hit here as hard as it hit
anywhere in America there was one big
difference at the factory that dominates
life here Marvin windows and doors
promised no layoffs still these are not
times of Plenty in Warroad the fortunes
of the Marvin company are tied to the
housing industry Susan Marvin the
president of the family-owned company
offers a bleak assessment housing starts
peaked at over 2 million and they
dropped down to roughly a half a million
we're bouncing on the bottom but
somewhere between 500 and 600 thousand
and little does that matter when you
were at two million and you drop down to
500 and you bounce up to 550 it's really
just such a very small market compared
to what it used to be less new
construction means fewer windows and
doors that means a smaller number of
orders for Marvin and less work so
although the factory hasn't cut jobs all
of its workers have felt the pain Marvin
windows and doors has reduced offseason
hours it has cancelled overtime and cut
benefits like 401 K matching and profit
sharing some workers have taken second
jobs to make ends meet or to stay on top
of debts when you've been here and
you've seen the good times you want to
get back to the good times as soon as
possible I'm working 40 hours a week at
Marvin's
and then I'm working roughly about 25
hours here anywhere from 15 to 2 40 a
week but I average about 25 hours a week
here Doug's I don't know if it's a
recession that we ran over for the
depression that will rent in the housing
industry right now and not an economist
so I don't know but it's just very
difficult time you have to take a look
at your lifestyle and secure what
changes do I have to make what are some
of the things that were things that I
wanted before but now I'm focusing and
what are the things that I need Susan
Marvin believes in her company cannot
count on an economic improvement for
success or survival there isn't a metric
out there that indicates we're going to
experience a recovery so you sit there
and you go ok we can sustain the
business operating like we are and wait
for it to improve or we can say that's
just plain not good enough and we're
going to do something about it and we
want to grow and we want to be more
prosperous this is Mac William bishop
reporting from Warroad Minnesota for the
New York Times
you
